So said  Curt Sampson  on  2003-02-06 --------------------

>On Mon, 3 Feb 2003, Scott Stirling wrote:
>
>> One thing I don't think we ever discussed is the fact that, in the
>> case we were discussing, the mock object approach allows you to
>> separate your test from the database connection.
>
>In this case the test *was* the database connection.
>
>I try to minimize the number of tests that hit the database, but I've
>done enough inserts to and reads from the wrong columns that I try to
>test each SQL statement I execute.

Pushing every SQL statement you use out to a ResourceBundle (or other
metadata file) is a good idea. It's very easy to write a single test
that runs through all the SQL statements in the metadata file and do a
sanity check on them: can I read the columns from the tables I SELECT?
and so on.

The other thing would be to have a single source for both the database
schema and the SQL statements in your code. I haven't tried it yet, but
it looks like a great idea.

>And then generally I create mock versions of those objects that
actually
>do database work so that I can test everything else without touching
the
>database.

To me, what's important is to verify your SQL statements and that you
can make objects out of ResultSets. Beyond that, you're testing the
database.
